content:
Section 12 covers Non-Assignment and Discharge, stating that the insurer will not recognize or be affected by any notice of trust, charge, or assignment relating to this Policy. The receipt of the insured, or their legal personal representatives, or of any person(s) to whom any benefit is expressed to be payable shall in all cases effectively discharge the insurer's liability.

Section 13 addresses Other Insurance, indicating that if at the time any claim arises under this Policy there is any other insurance policy effected by or on behalf of the insured covering the same expenses, the insurer shall not be liable to pay or contribute more than its ratable proportion of any claim for such expense.

Section 14 discusses the Premium Before Cover Warranty, stating that the premium due must be paid to the insurer (or the intermediary through whom this Policy or the insurance was arranged).



---

# Page 11
questions: What does Section 12 state about the insurer's recognition of trust or assignment notices?
Who can effectively discharge the insurer's liability according to Section 12?
What happens if there is another insurance policy covering the same expenses as this Policy?
How does Section 13 affect the insurer's liability in the event of a claim?
What is required regarding the premium before coverage is provided according to Section 14?
Can the insured assign their rights under this Policy to another party?
What is the significance of the receipt from the insured or their representatives in discharging the insurer's liability?
How does the presence of other insurance policies impact the claims process under this Policy?
What does the term 'ratable proportion' mean in the context of Section 13?
Is it possible for the insurer to be liable for the full amount of a claim if there are multiple insurance policies involved?
